title: R46361
content: The report provides an overview of the FY2020 Defense Appropriations Act (P.L. 116-93) and serves as a gateway to other CRS products offering additional context and analysis related to the legislation. It tracks the legislative history, budgetary context, and treatment of major components of the Trump Administration's budget request, including weapons acquisition programs. The Administration requested $750.0 billion in discretionary budget authority for FY2020. The Trump Administration requested $750.0 billion for national defense in FY2020, with $718.3 billion allocated for Department of Defense activities. $689.5 billion of the DOD budget fell within the defense appropriations bill. The FY2020 defense appropriations bill allocated $1.1 billion for intelligence community expenses. It does not include funding for military construction, family housing, or TRICARE for Life program. Funding for these activities is provided by separate appropriations bills. The FY2020 Defense Appropriations Act, part of H.R. 1158, provides $687.8 billion for DOD, $2.86 billion less than requested by President Trump. Since 2001, DOD has structured its budget to allocate funds for post-9/11 activities and base budget costs. The DOD's "base budget" covers regular costs for U.S. armed forces, while non-base budget funds are designated for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO). The Budget Control Act of 2011 set annual spending caps, but OCO funds are exempt from these caps. The FY2020 defense budget included OCO funding to avoid exceeding spending caps. Committees treated OCO funds as part of the base budget request. The FY2020 defense budget included OCO funding to avoid exceeding spending caps. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2019 raised the defense spending cap to $666.5 billion for FY2020, rendering the issue of "OCO for base" funds moot. Separate versions of the FY2020 defense appropriations bill were reported by the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. The House passed H.R. 2740 incorporating the text of H.R. 2968, while the Senate reported S. 2474. The House passed H.R. 2740 on June 19, 2019, incorporating the text of H.R. 2968. The Senate reported S. 2474 on September 12, 2019, but took no action. A compromise version of the defense bill was included in H.R. 1158, which was passed by both chambers.
